adumbrate: [verb] to foreshadow or to outline without clear details
agglomeration: [noun] a grouping or collection of many things
amalgamation: [noun] the result or process of multiple things blending
amass: [verb] to gather or collect in large amounts
anticipatory: [adj.] done or felt due to an upcoming event
discomfit: [verb] to make someone feel embarrassed or uncomfortable
dissent: [verb] to publicly disagree with a belief
footle: [verb] to waste time or act foolishly
forage: [verb] to search for food or other supplies
glint: [noun] a small flash of light or sparkle
hinterland: [noun] a remote region or inland area beyond city limits
increment: [noun] an amount a value changes by, especially a fixed amount
intelligentsia: [noun] a group of usually influential intellectuals
jostle: [verb] to push or bump against roughly
patrician: [noun] a person of noble or high rank
portent: [noun] an omen or sign that something is likely to happen
prevaricate: [verb] to not tell the truth, often by avoiding a question
procurator: [noun] someone who manages another's legal or business affairs
splenetic: [adj.] cranky, touchy, in a bad mood
stratify: [verb] to form or arrange into layers
trope: [noun] a common theme or device in storytelling
tyro: [noun] someone inexperienced or new to something, a novice
